title: Level 1 Statistics Practice Test
description: Test your skills with surveys, picture graphs, and chance!

questions.question: In a survey, 9 children chose red, 5 chose blue, and 6 chose green as their favourite colour. Which colour was the most popular?
questions.explanation: Compare the numbers: Red = 9, Blue = 5, Green = 6. The biggest number is 9, so red was the most popular colour.

questions.question: A picture graph shows: Cats -- 4 pictures, Dogs -- 7 pictures, Fish -- 2 pictures. How many children were surveyed altogether?
questions.explanation: Add all the pictures: 4 + 7 + 2 = 13. There were 13 children surveyed altogether.

questions.question: Which of these events 'won't happen' (is impossible)?

options.text: The sun will rise in the morning
A dog will talk in English
You might see a bird today

questions.explanation: Dogs cannot speak in English -- that is impossible, so it won't happen. Rain tomorrow might happen, the sun rising will happen, and seeing a bird might happen.

questions.question: What do tally marks help us do?
questions.explanation: Tally marks are a quick way to record and count answers when doing a survey. Every 5th mark goes across the other four, making groups of 5 that are easy to count.

questions.question: A picture graph has a row of 8 pictures for apples and a row of 5 pictures for bananas. How many more children chose apples?
questions.explanation: To find 'how many more', subtract: 8 - 5 = 3. Three more children chose apples than bananas.

questions.question: If you drop a ball, it will fall to the ground. This is an example of something that:
questions.explanation: Gravity always pulls things down. If you drop a ball, it will definitely fall to the ground. This is certain -- it will happen every time.

questions.question: A survey found: Pizza -- 10 children, Sushi -- 4 children, Pasta -- 6 children. Which food was the least popular?
questions.explanation: Compare the numbers: Pizza = 10, Sushi = 4, Pasta = 6. The smallest number is 4, so sushi was the least popular.

questions.question: A picture graph shows: Sunny days -- 5 pictures, Rainy days -- 3 pictures, Cloudy days -- 2 pictures. How many days were recorded altogether?
questions.explanation: Add all the pictures: 5 + 3 + 2 = 10. There were 10 days recorded altogether.

questions.question: It might snow in July in Melbourne. Is this something that 'will happen', 'might happen', or 'won't happen'?
questions.explanation: July is winter in Melbourne, and it occasionally snows, though it is not common. Since it could happen but is not certain, we say it 'might happen'.

questions.question: In a survey, 7 children chose cats and 7 chose dogs. Do more children prefer cats, dogs, or is it the same?
questions.explanation: Both cats and dogs got 7 votes each. Since the numbers are equal, the same number of children prefer cats as dogs.
